Award.AwardTitle: Combustion of Highly Strained Hydrocarbons: Non-Intrusive Isomer Specific Detection of Complex Combustion Intermediates

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336105
Weber

Combustion reactions are of great importance for basic combustion science as well as for the development of efficient and clean engines. Highly strained hydrocarbons are of particular interest since they are candidates for high-energy density fuels. Established techniques for flame composition analysis, such as VUV photoionization mass spectrometry, IR or Raman spectroscopy are difficult because either the molecules can isomerizes on their way to a detector, or the high temperature of the flame makes spectra too complex to analyze. This project develops a novel technique, Rydberg Fingerprint Spectroscopy, to identify the molecular compounds in the flame. Following calibration and comparison with data from a molecular beam photoionization implementation, the technique will use a radar method for in-flame analysis. The technique enables non-intrusive and in-situ detection of complex molecular species and reveals highly resolved spectra that are molecular structure sensitive while being insensitive toward temperature. Consequently, the method is promising for sampling flame components at the high temperature of a flame. We explore the combustion of quadricyclane and norbornadiene, highly strained hydrocarbons with the formula C7H8. The proposed new method for flame diagnostics can also be used for future combustion science studies and for commercial implementations. The project will involve one graduate student and form the basis of the student?s dissertation. The PI will work with Leadership Alliance, a national consortium headquartered at Brown University enhancing undergraduate students? interest in pursuing graduate education and success in their careers.

Institution.Name: Brown University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BROWN UNIVERSITY IN PROVIDENCE IN THE STATE OF RHODE ISLAND AND PROVIDENCE PLANTATIONS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the proposed research is detection of combustion intermediates via structure sensitive photoionization through Rydberg states followed by detection of the laser induced plasma via microwave radiation. In other words, the objective is to identify molecules that might be present in flames: what kind of species are formed, how are they formed, and where in a flame might they be? To explore these questions, Rydberg state spectroscopy was used.  Transitions between molecular Rydberg states are not encumbered by vibrational congestion, thus revealing spectra that are largely independent of the temperature of the molecules. This makes Rydberg spectroscopy highly attractive for detection of combustion intermediates. In our research we demonstrated non-intrusive and in situ detection of methyl radicals in methane, propane, and n-hexane flames (F. Rudakov, Y. Gao, F., X. Cheng, P.M. Weber “Non-Intrusive Detection of Combustion Intermediates by Photoionization via Rydberg States and Microwave Backscattering” Combustion and Flames, 171, 162–167 (2016)) as well polyatomic combustion intermediates (tetramethylethylene in tetramethylethane flame). We also explored the effect of structural dispersion on the Rydberg spectrum in multiple molecules.

The outcome of the project then had two parts: on the methodology side we invented a technique that is capable of identifying molecules - something that had been a longstanding problem. And secondly, specific model systems were studied, giving us further insights into flame chemistry.


Last Modified: 11/15/2018
Modified by: Peter M Weber

In other words, the objective is to identify molecules that might be present in flames: what kind of species are formed, how are they formed, and where in a flame might they be? To explore these questions, Rydberg state spectroscopy was used. Transitions between molecular Rydberg states are not encumbered by vibrational congestion, thus revealing spectra that are largely independent of the temperature of the molecules. This makes Rydberg spectroscopy highly attractive for detection of combustion intermediates. In our research we demonstrated non-intrusive and in situ detection of methyl radicals in methane, propane, and n-hexane flames (F. Rudakov, Y. Gao, F., X. Cheng, P.M. Weber "Non-Intrusive Detection of Combustion Intermediates by Photoionization via Rydberg States and Microwave Backscattering" Combustion and Flames, 171, 162–167 (2016)) as well polyatomic combustion intermediates (tetramethylethylene in tetramethylethane flame). We also explored the effect of structural dispersion on the Rydberg spectrum in multiple molecules. The outcome of the project then had two parts: on the methodology side we invented a technique that is capable of identifying molecules - something that had been a longstanding problem.
